Award.AwardTitle: UNS: Collaborative Research: Describing Macromolecular Transport through Chemically-Tuned Nanoporous Membranes via Theory, Computation, and Experiment

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Collaborative Proposals

#1511835 / #1511862
Boudouris, Bryan / Phillip, William

Membranes are crucial in a number of separation processes where desired products are isolated from undesired species. In particular, many emerging pharmaceutical treatments require the purification of active long-chain biomacromolecules as they leave the biopharmaceutical reactor. These biomacromolecules recently have been approved for the treatment of a variety of life-threatening diseases, including cancer and autoimmune diseases. However, the high cost of large-scale production and purification of these important materials, which is often transferred to the patient, has prevented their widespread implementation in clinical practice. This proposal will evaluate how macromolecules such as these important therapeutic agents are transported through membrane materials. By combining experimental results with theoretical predictions and computational simulations, a complete picture of how transport occurs through small pores will be developed. This opens the potential of generating more cost-effective purification systems, which could lessen the costs of patient treatment and open an economical means by which to treat a number of devastating diseases.

The transport of macromolecular species is of fundamental import in a range of technologically-important membrane separations applications (e.g., the separation of therapeutic proteins). However, the exact mechanism of how a dissolved polymer chain traverses a membrane with pore sizes comparable to or smaller than the hydrodynamic diameter of the chain at thermodynamic equilibrium and without external stimuli (e.g., applied electric fields) is not understood fully. As such, a critical need exists to establish how pore size, pore chemistry, and the solution environment affect the interfacial transport of macromolecules across well-structured membranes. Here, a combination of experimental techniques, thermodynamic theory, and computational modeling is utilized in order to tie nanoscale phenomena to physical observables at the macroscopic level. The vision will result in a molecule-to-membrane level understanding of chemically-selective macromolecular transport through small pores; this understanding, which will be developed by connecting continuum transport properties to molecular models through advanced materials characterization methodologies, will enable the PIs to develop the design principles for the rational engineering of chemically-selective membranes in a number of current and emerging separations platforms.

Generating structure-property-performance relationships in the realm of size and chemically-selective membranes will lead to improved membrane design. This, in turn, will help decrease production costs and increase the energy efficiency of many processes required for the production of common consumer goods and more high-value products (e.g., therapeutic pharmaceuticals). As such, successful completion of this work has the potential to impact current manufacturing processes in a positive manner. Furthermore, the collaboration between Purdue University and the University of Notre Dame will allow students from both institutions to perform work at the partner institution. In this way, the students will have a more diverse educational experience. In addition to graduate students, undergraduate and high school students will perform research on this project. In particular, the high school student will be part of the American Chemical Society's Project SEED program. Therefore, this work has the ability to advance fundamental membrane science and to impact a unique group of interdisciplinary scientists and engineers with diverse socioeconomic and educational backgrounds.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purification of water using membrane separations in low-cost, low-energy, and environmentally-friendly manners is a critical opportunity facing society. This is especially true given the recent concerns regarding the contamination of drinking water supplies with heavy metals in communities across the United States. Here, we have made significant inroads in addressing this crucial issue through a combination of theory, computation, and experiment. In particular, we have been able to design and synthesize new polymeric materials, control their nanoscale structure, and use these materials in applications to elucidate the underlying principles that govern the removal of metal cations from water supplies. Importantly, all of these efforts have been based on the concept of block polymer membranes that have been fabricated using the self-assembly and non-solvent induced phase separation (SNIPS) casting technique. The mechanism of this technique relies on tuning the molecular weight and composition of the block polymer while controlling the processing conditions of the material. If both of these parameters are adjusted in the appropriate manner, as we have done here, it leads to nanoporous membranes with pore sizes on the order of 1 – 10 nm in size. These platform membranes have allowed us to address the fundamental principles of water purification. In particular, we have accomplished this overarching Intellectual Merit goal through three distinct efforts.

 

In the first of these efforts, we were able to identify the key properties regarding the water chemistry that allowed for the manipulation of the polymer chains that extended from the nanopores of the membrane. In examining the polymer physics associated with these chain rearrangements we were able to quantify how the membranes fabricated in our laboratories would respond to various stimuli during the water purification process. In this way, it provided a firm foundation for what operating conditions were of utility for our membrane, and alternatively, regions of space in which we were not able to operate. Based upon this feedback, we were able to modify the chemical design of the block polymer membranes in order to generate more robust operating systems.

 

In the second of these efforts, we refined the membrane molecular design to included bio-inspired chemical functionalities on the surface of the pores of the nanofiltration membrane to create a device capable of separating components based both on size and chemical identity. These membrane adsorbers performed extremely well in testing of systems that mimicked what was observed across the United States in a number of drinking water crises (e.g., in Flint, MI). In particular, glutathione- and mercapto-based chemistries were utilized to selectively remove > 93% and > 96% of the cadmium and lead ions that were dissolved in solution, respectively. Even at relatively high, yet realistic, feed concentrations of the dissolved heavy metal salts, the bio-inspired membranes were able to remove enough of the material to make the product water within the range that is deemed safe for drinking by U.S. agencies. Importantly, the nanostructure of the membrane that results from the SNIPS casting process creates a separation device that has a plentiful number of sites with which the heavy metal cations can interact. Thus, the capacity of the membrane is quite large.

 

In the final aspect of this proposal, the molecular design of the membrane was refined again. In this case, the functionality of the pore wall chemistry was tuned in order to generate a system that was remarkably robust to changes in the pH and ionic strength of the feed water solution. In this way, these next-generation membranes were able to achieve Angstrom-level selectivity when operated in conditions that included the presence of relatively high concentrations of background electrolytes. Additionally, we were able to demonstrate that this type of selectivity occurred in a hollow fiber membrane geometry, which is consistent with the manufacturing of small footprint membrane modules. In this way, the fundamental science developed by this proposal has a clear technology transition pathway forward for future commercial endeavors as well.

 

In addition to making all of these Intellectual Merit impacts, the work performed in this proposal also made significant inroads with respect to Broader Impacts as well. First, two undergraduate and two graduate students at Purdue University participated in student exchanges at the University of Notre Dame. This allowed the chemistry-focused students to have practical experience with membrane fabrication and membrane testing. Additionally, the two graduate students and one of the undergraduate students associated with this project were women, with one of those graduate students being of Hispanic/Latina heritage. Finally, we expect that the results of this work should be translatable to practice in a rather direct manner due to the scalable manufacturing processes used to generate the membranes of this effort. Therefore, this work has made an impact both inside and outside the walls of Purdue University.
